awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Study of Dopants Effect for Stable Hybrid Perovskite Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: Dopants govern and regulate a variety of electronic, optical, thermal and mechanical properties, thus playing a pivotal role in various materials research ranging from metals, semiconductors and insulators. Therefore, fundamental insights to the dopants effect on emerging materials provide a versatile kit to radically tailor the material properties to best fit in their desired practical applications and even lead to discovery of new materials and applications. As a game-changing player in the field of photovoltaics, organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites materials (HPM) has exhibited impressive photovoltaic efficiency. However, HPM still suffer from major challenges including chemical instability and lead toxicity due to: (i) hydration effects, leading to structural failure and (ii) formation of vacancy defects, leading to poor carrier lifetime. In this project, the research team aims to understand the various dopants in HPM and to pursue their synergistic effect towards stable HPM based on fundamental chemical principles. Meanwhile, as an effective way to train the next generation of scientists, the team aims to work with the nearby world-class research facilities at Argonne National Laboratory through existing collaborations with Argonne scientists such that both graduate and undergraduate students with wide diversities can be involved in frontline research projects at their young age, and trained with skills in cutting-edge facilities, interdisciplinary knowledge, critical thinking, problem solving, and team work. 

Technical Description: The project has a two-fold objective, namely to establish the relationship between dopants (type, amount and location) and the chemical stability of the HPM while minimizing the loss in PV performance; and to provide an atomic level understanding of how the proposed dopants stabilize the vulnerable ions in HPM and affect their PV performance. A synergistic co-doping of both cations and anions is conducted to study their effect on the overall chemical stability. The team is also exploring the interplay between charge-isotropic cationic dopants and multivalent anionic dopants, which are hypothesized to enhance electrostatic coupling between the cationic and anionic parts in HPM, and thus enabling greater rigidity of the overall perovskite structure. The research involves the use of dopants capable of forming strong hydrogen bonding at the atomic level gateway of the perovskite structure to effectively block the ingression of water molecules. Furthermore, the research also involves the use of selected reducing dopants to suppress oxidation of Sn2+ to Sn4+ in Sn-based HPM, based on understanding of what and how reductants can retard the oxidation of Sn2+. Additionally, a high pressure technique is used to minimize the Sn2+ vacancy defects in Sn-based HPM. By prudently designing the type, amount and location of the dopants towards minimal loss in PV efficiency and maximal stability enhancement benefited from the dopants, the ultimate research goal is to provide a clear path to atomically reinforced structure of HPM using dopants as the stabilizing rivets in order to achieve stable and lead-free perovskite solar cells.

This NSF project addressed various real-world challenges via in-depth basic research in electronic, photonic and magnetic properties of hybrid perovskite materials. The latest progress in solution-processed organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites solar cells (PSCs) is reshaping the growth pattern of any prior photovoltaic technologies, as “trademarked” by their soaring power conversion efficiency over 25%. However, PSCs are still facing a critical materials science triathlon challenge in stability, scalability and toxicity. Overcoming these hurdles requires a comprehensive basic science understanding so as to render crucial fundamental clues towards better photovoltaic (PV) materials and beyond. Image-1.

Toxicity: Through fundamental coordination chemistry, we developed an on-device lead sequestering mechanism to mitigate the potential leakage of toxic lead from PSC to environment. All high-performance perovskite solar cells contains water-soluble lead contents and non-tempered transparent conducting oxide (TCO) glass. Thus, future commercialization of PSC is subject to tight environmental and safety regulations. Based on the charge-ligand interaction, we developed a lead-absorbing solar EVA film technology, offering an excellent solution to form laminated safety TCO glass to minimize lead leakage to environment or to residential area. Nature, 2020, 578, 555. This work was also highlighted by NSF and Scientific American. Image-2

Scalability: Most reported champion PSC use vacuum deposited gold as the back contact electrode for its high work function for charge extraction and high conductivity for charge transport to external circuit. However, vacuum deposition equipment accounts for >50% of the capital equipment cost and 50% manufacturing energy cost for PSC. Meanwhile, gold is too expensive to use at scale (8 tons of gold is needed for 1GW of PSC, not to mention the wasted gold during vacuum deposition). We show that by allocating the high work function and high conductivity to two separate materials, a bilayer electrode consisting of nature graphite (for its high work function) and low-melting point metal alloy (for its high conductivity) can replace the role of gold in PSC with PV performance compatible with that of gold-based PSC. More strikingly, both nature graphite and metal alloy can be laminated under ambient pressure, thus circumventing the expensive vacuum coating process. ACS Energy Letters, 2023, 8, 2940-2945. This work was also highlighted by Chemical & Engineering News, a news magazine of American Chemical Society. Image-3.

Stability: We show that replacing the agile hydrogen in A-site cation with its non-radioactive but twice heavier isotope deuterium offers a low-cost approach to retard the degradation reaction kinetics of hybrid perovskites, thus to improve stability of PSC as an independent add-on feature that is adaptable to any existing PSC formula. PNAS Nexus, 2023, 2(5), pgad160. Image-4.

In addition, by doping the divalent anion Se2− in the form of PbSe in precursor solutions, we also demonstrated the enhancement of the hydrogen-bonding-like interactions between the organic cations and the inorganic framework. As a result, in 100% humidity at 40 °C, the 10% w/w PbSe-doped perovskite films exhibited >140-fold stability improvement over pristine perovskite films. As a bonus, the incorporated Se2− also effectively suppresses iodine diffusion, leading to enhanced chemical stability of the silver electrodes. Adv. Mater., 2018, 30, 1800973. 

Beyond PV: Using hybrid perovskites as an exploratory platform, we also enriched our fundamental understanding in the structure-property correlation of optoelectronic materials and the spintronics via light-matter interaction for quantum information science.

Metastable materials often exhibit unexpected striking properties that are not available in stable state. While metastable states are generally achieved by rapid cooling of materials from high temperature, it is imperative to explore other nonthermal routes to access metastable states, especially for heat-vulnerable materials. Here, we report that work by pressure, namely, a compression−decompression cycle under ambient temperature, can drive thermally susceptible hybrid perovskites to their metastable state, in which the perovskites show enduring bandgap narrowing for significantly broadened solar absorption. This pressure-derived route provides a fundamental path to obtain metastable materials with unprecedented performance. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A., 2018, 115, 8076-8081. 

Tuning the properties of a pair of entangled electron and hole in a light-induced exciton is a fundamentally intriguing inquiry for quantum science. Using semiconducting hybrid perovskite as an exploratory platform, we discover that Nd2+-doped perovskite exhibits a Kondo-like exciton-spin interaction under cryogenic and photoexcitation conditions. The feedback to such interaction between excitons in perovskite and the localized spins in Nd2+ is observed as notably prolonged carrier lifetimes measured by time-resolved photoluminescence, ~10 times to that of pristine perovskite without Nd2+ dopant. Such extended charge separation states are the consequence of the trap state enabled by the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction between the light-induced exciton and the localized 4 f spins of the Nd2+ in the proximity. This Kondo-like exciton-spin interaction is responsive to spin doping concentration and external magnetic field, providing a new quantum sensing mechanism to spin environment. Nature Communication, 2024, 15, 6084.  Image-5.
